q: What are the symptoms of Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease?
a: The symptoms of Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease include muscle weakness in the feet, ankles, legs, and hands; an awkward way of walking; highly arched or very flat feet; and numbness in the feet, arms, and hands.

q: What causes Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease?
a: Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease is caused by an inherited fault in one of the genes responsible for the development of the peripheral nerves.

q: How is Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease diagnosed?
a: If you suspect you have Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease, see your GP who may refer you to a neurologist for further tests to confirm the diagnosis.

q: How is Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease treated?
a: There is currently no cure for Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease, but treatments can help relieve symptoms and improve mobility. These may include physiotherapy, certain types of exercise, occupational therapy, and the use of walking aids.

q: What is the impact of living with Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease?
a: Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease is not life-threatening, but it can make everyday activities difficult and have a significant emotional impact. Support groups and therapies such as cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) can be helpful.

q: What is the main charity and support group for people with Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease in the UK?
a: The main charity and support group for people with Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease in the UK is CMT UK. They provide information, support, and practical advice for living with the condition.

q: What is the role of the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service in relation to Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease?
a: The National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service (NCARDRS) collects information about individuals with Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease in order to help scientists find better ways to prevent and treat the condition.

q: Can surgery be a treatment option for Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease?
a: In some cases, surgery may be needed to correct problems such as flat feet and muscle contractures in individuals with Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease.

q: Are there any specific exercises that can help with Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease?
a: Physiotherapy and certain types of exercise can be beneficial for individuals with Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease in managing symptoms and improving mobility.

q: Is Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease hereditary?
a: Yes, Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease is caused by inherited genetic faults and can be passed on from parents to their children.

q: What are the symptoms of Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease?
a: The symptoms of Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease include muscle weakness in the feet, ankles, legs, and hands, an awkward way of walking (gait), highly arched or very flat feet, and numbness in the feet, arms, and hands. These symptoms usually start to appear between the ages of 5 and 15.

q: How is Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease caused?
a: Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease is caused by an inherited fault in one of the many genes responsible for the development of the peripheral nerves. This inherited fault leads to the progressive damage of the nerves over time.

q: What tests are conducted to diagnose Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease?
a: If your GP suspects Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease, they will refer you to a neurologist for further tests to confirm the diagnosis. These tests may include a neurological examination and genetic testing.

q: Is there a cure for Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease?
a: There is currently no cure for Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease. However, treatments such as physiotherapy, certain types of exercise, occupational therapy, and walking aids can help relieve symptoms, improve mobility, and increase quality of life.

q: How does Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease affect daily life?
a: Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease can make everyday activities very difficult. However, it is not life-threatening, and most people with the condition have the same life expectancy as those without it. Emotional support, such as speaking to others with the condition or undergoing cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT), can be helpful.

q: Where can I find more information and support for Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease?
a: You can find more information, support, and practical advice about living with Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease on the Charcot-Marie-Tooth UK website. CMT UK is the main charity and support group for people with Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease in the UK.

q: How can I opt out of the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service (NCARDRS)?
a: If you have Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease, your clinical team will pass information about you to the NCARDRS. If you wish to opt out of the register at any time, you can inform your clinical team.

q: What are the treatment options for Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease?
a: Treatment options for Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease may include physiotherapy, specific exercises, occupational therapy, and the use of walking aids. In some cases, surgery may be necessary to correct problems like flat feet and muscle contractures.

q: At what age do the symptoms of Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease usually start to appear?
a: The symptoms of Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease typically start to appear between the ages of 5 and 15. However, in some cases, they may not develop until middle age or later.

q: How can I find better ways to prevent and treat Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease?
a: If you have Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease, your clinical team will pass information about you to the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service (NCARDRS). This helps scientists in their research to find better ways to prevent and treat the condition.
